newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends limit-up on stop loss buying.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends limit-up on stop loss buying.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended mostly limit-up on Monday, the first trading session after the Lunar New Year holiday, on stop loss buying triggered by world price gains over the past two weeks, traders said.
The most active May 1997 contract ended limit-up at 22,100 yuan ($2,665) per tonne, rising 520 yuan. It opened at an intraday low of 21,980 yuan.
March rose 520 to 22,120, April 550 to 22,130, June 550 to 22,100, July 600 to 22,100 and August 340 to 22,200.
Combined volume fell to 12,120 tonnes from 46,110.
Traders noted the rises in London Metal Exchange copper prices during the past two weeks, when China closed down to celebrate the arrival of the Year of the Ox.
"Monday's stop loss buying pushed the prices to limit-up early in the session but volume was thin with few investors willing to sell at current levels," one trader said.
He said traders expected copper to rise further following Monday's breach of the 21,800-22,000 strong resistance level.
Traders said firm domestic spot copper prices of around 22,000 yuan per tonne in Shanghai, also supported the rises on the futures market.
Some traders said current world over-supply of copper was not a condition likely to change in the short-term.
"Domestic demand is also not likely to rise sharply in 1997 despite China's booming economy," another trader said.
Aluminium ended up. March rose 100 to 15,600 yuan per tonne, April 210 to 15,900 and May 120 to 16,000. The first traded June contract ended at 16,000 yuan tonne.
Combined volume rose to 2,070 tonnes from 1,120.
